member.name: IAudioCaptureClient.GetNextPacketSize
member.summary: The GetNextPacketSize method retrieves the number of frames in the next data packet in the capture endpoint buffer.
member.param: Pointer to a UINT32 variable into which the method writes the frame count (the number of audio frames in the next capture packet).

returns.para: If the method succeeds, it returns S_OK. If it fails, possible return codes include, but are not limited to, the values shown in the following table.

listheader.description: The audio endpoint device has been unplugged, or the audio hardware or associated hardware resources have been reconfigured, disabled, removed, or otherwise made unavailable for use.
The Windows audio service is not running.

member.summary: The ReleaseBuffer method releases the buffer.
member.param: The number of audio frames that the client read from the capture buffer. This parameter must be either equal to the number of frames in the previously acquired data packet or 0.

returns.para: If the method succeeds, it returns S_OK. If it fails, possible return codes include, but are not limited to, the values shown in the following table.

summary.para: The IAudioCaptureClient interface enables a client to read input data from a capture endpoint buffer. The client obtains a reference to the IAudioCaptureClient interface on a stream object by calling the method with parameter riid set to REFIID IID_IAudioCaptureClient.

The methods in this interface manage the movement of data packets that contain capture data. The length of a data packet is expressed as the number of audio frames in the packet. The size of an audio frame is specified by the nBlockAlign member of the WAVEFORMATEX (or WAVEFORMATEXTENSIBLE) structure that the client obtains by calling the method. The size in bytes of an audio frame equals the number of channels in the stream multiplied by the sample size per channel. For example, the frame size is four bytes for a stereo (2-channel) stream with 16-bit samples. A packet always contains an integral number of audio frames.
When releasing an IAudioCaptureClient interface instance, the client must call the Release method of the instance from the same thread as the call to IAudioClient.GetService that created the object.
For a code example that uses the IAudioCaptureClient interface, see Capturing a Stream.
